ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about the fascinating world of Victorian literature while continuing to hone my close-reading skills!

I got much better at engaging with secondary sources about aspects of the novels we read and discussed in class. I definitely grew as a writer in this class, and really enjoyed thinking about the ways each of the books we read has been "problematic" for readers and reviewers since its publication. The class discussions with Professor Yeazell and Colton were always thought provoking and engaging, and I gained a new appreciation for some books I'd read before, as well as discovering others I hadn't.

My ability to read and analyze long, often challenging books improved so much. I also learned a lot about the Victorian novel -- its conventions, its form, and the role it played in 19th century England.
Skill in close-reading of 19c novel, awareness of range of 19c novel, skill in constructing written arguments about them, learning to engage with contemporary and modern criticidm
We read a few very interesting Victorian writers including Dickens and Bronte.
This was a very challenging but rewarding English class. As one of my first upper level English courses, the focus on criticism was new to me, but very interesting.
My writing and critical thinking skills improved

I delved into four major works of Victorian fiction and, through this, learned about the defining characteristics of the genre as a whole. I practiced my close reading skills and analytical writing abilities.
Deep analytical skills, strong English roundtable, Victorian-era familiarity
How to interpret novels
This class introduced me to a range of unique Victorian novels. It also engaged with secondary criticism from both modern and Victorian thinkers. I think it improved my reading ability.
Early to mid-century Victorian literature.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This was one of the best courses I've taken during my time at Yale!  Seminar discussions about power, femininity, and social custom were some of the best I've had, and each of the books were worth multiple reads in their own rights.  I looked forward to every day I had class.

This was a really amazing class. I looked forward to it every time, and had a blast in each discussion. The reading load *can* get heavy (they warn you about this day one!) but it's mostly manageable, although the last book pushed me a bit with some readings close to 150 pages needing to get done between Monday and Wednesday. The writing requirement is just three papers, but they are not easy papers to write. However, if you make use of the instructor office hours they are definitely doable - they are willing to workshop ideas with you and discuss drafts as well, so really helpful. There are a number of curated secondary sources made available to you, and you can also bring in ones of your own if you find them. Overall, great class!

The greatest strength was certainly Prof. Yeazell and Colton's expertise and excellent teaching. Beyond that, the biggest strength of the course was the quality of the discussions. It was really amazing to take in everyone's brilliance, even when it felt a little overwhelming. 
The reading load was higher than any course I've taken here, but no weaknesses.

Both instructors were immaculately prepared. Excellent discussions. Excellent feedback on written work.

Try to get through Woman in White in a week? Or nix it. I felt it wasn't of the same order as the other novels on the syllabus and consequently the discussions weren't quite of the same quality. 

4 weeks on Bleak House also felt a little much. It's not actually that much longer than Middlemarch which can be done in 3. That would adds in space to get another 3 week novel in place of Woman in White, or even two shorter novels (1.5 weeks each)

Strengths: the texts were interesting and important; Professor Yeazell and Colton had great chemistry and the class was quite engaging. Weaknesses: this class is A LOT of reading (which can be good or bad depending on what you are looking for)! I found that the papers were also a bit restricting, with prompts being centered around a review of the literature. The two papers were quite short and then the final paper was very long which I found to be slightly jarring. That being said, the feedback from the professors was very thoughtful

I absolutely loved the four novels we read for this course. Professors Yeazell and Valentine did an excellent job of co-teaching the course by alternating who lead the seminars. I occasionally wished that discussions could be more grounded in the texts; my favorite seminars were the ones when our professors came in with a key passage or two, and we expanded outward from there. The Bleak House screening and Beinecke visit were wonderful additions to the course. As far as assignments go, I particularly enjoyed interacting with Victorian critics in the Villette paper and might have enjoyed the second short paper more if it had focused on Victorian rather than modern criticism.
This course is a lot of work but well worth it to be in such an engaging and interesting learning environment.

srengths: the books were well chosen, written by popular authors but not works I had read before 
weaknesses: the high reading load was difficult to manage at times, even though we received warning of that at the beginning
Strengths - Prof. Yeazell & Colton were AMAZING. Great co-teaching pair, and they facilitated amazing discussions. Weaknesses - a lot of reading
If you don't like the books being discussed it's not great, if you do it's wonderful
I think this course was well-structured and taught and the classroom discussions were thrilling. At times I would have desired a bit more feedback or assistance on papers.
Both Colton and Professor Yeazell were very knowledgeable. They took it in turns to lead the class, which worked well enough.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes!  Victorian literature is a fairly underrated literary time period.  It definitely doesn't get as much attention as other eras might, but this course made me fall in love with all the authors and characters on the page!  You learn to read, but also to notice--we spent so much time in class discussing character foils, triangulations, and all the fascinating patterns that novelists weave into the pages.

I would absolutely recommend this class to anyone interested in reading four very interesting books, and thoroughly discussing them! There's a lot to talk about, since they are "problem" novels, and the class discussion was always the best part of my day.  Do be ready for some heavy reading though.
Absolutely. If you have an interest in Victorian literature, take this course!!
Yes. If you want to learn about the 19c novel, this is the course for you. The course also stands out for the quality of feedback one receives on written work.
The course is a lot of reading and the papers were not very satisfying in my experience. Take this course if you want to read a lot of Victorian literature.
Absolutely! Everyone seemed to love the four novels we read in this course. If you're willing to put in the time to do the readings (around 120 - 150 pages per class), it's worth it.
Yes. This course is challenging with the workload and the level of engagement expected from students, but definitely worth taking. The professors were excellent and gave very helpful feedback.
Yes, if youre interested in the material! Its a lot of reading but very intellectually rewarding.
I would recommend this course to another student if they already have some experience with Victorian fiction and are at least a little sure that they like it.
Absolutely, if you want to take a rigorous English course, read classic novels, and explore formal literary "experiments!"
Yes, if you're willing to put in the time to read all the books, really smart people take this class and hearing their thoughts is great.

I would recommend this course to another student if they were interested in the subject matter and were prepared to undertake a large workload. This course has a lot of reading and many of the novels are very complex. I think for students who are ready to undertake a challenge it is a worthwhile course, but I would recommend people do not take the workload lightly.
Only if you have a passion for Victorian literature and you have plenty of time on your hands for reading.
